ended.note: Presented recall on or shortly before

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate.
Day of month not included on record copy of commission, which was issued during a recess of the Senate. Recommissioned on June 24, 1850, after confirmation.

ended.note: Left post on or soon after

chief.note: Culver's presentation of credentials on October 7, 1862 was disavowed by the U.S. Government. On January 12, 1863, Culver informed the Government of Venezuela that his status would revert to that existing before the presentation of his credentials. Culver presented new credentials on October 15, 1864, after a change of government.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate.

ended.note: Reported that the Government of Venezuela refused to have further dealings with him on

chief.note: Russell left Venezuela on February 17, 1877. He returned to post on March 17, 1878, to present his letter of recall, but he left post again on March 19, 1878, having not presented the letter because the Government of Venezuela refused to receive it.

Commissioned during a recess of the Senate. Was not issued a letter of credence, but entered into a “practical” relationship with the Government of Venezuela in September 1881, serving at Caracas until superseded.
As Baker had not presented a letter of recall in 1881, he resumed his functions as Minister Resident without a new commission. Resumed duties on May 16, 1882, without reaccreditation.

Received as Minister Resident only, since the laws of Venezuela prohibited recognition of dual diplomatic and consular capacities in the same individual. Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 8, 1884, after confirmation.

ended.note: Promoted to Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary

chief.note: Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on January 13, 1886, after confirmation.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 18, 1895, after confirmation.

ended.note: Recall requested by the Government of Venezuela

chief.note: Loomis left post on April 8, 1901.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 10, 1901, after confirmation.

Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 11, 1905, after confirmation. Russell left post on March 8, 1908. Jacob Sleeper was serving as Chargé d’Affaires ad interim on June 20, 1908, on which date he notified the Government of Venezuela that the United States had severed diplomatic relations with Venezuela. Russell presented new credentials on March 15, 1909, when diplomatic relations were re-established.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on December 9, 1947, after confirmation.
Left post on September 6, 2008, and returned on July 1, 2009.
Nomination of February 25, 1856, withdrawn before the Senate acted upon it.
Commissioned during a recess of the Senate; recommissioned on July 5, 1861, after confirmation. Proceeded to post but did not present credentials; left Venezuela on February 22, 1862.
Not commissioned; nomination withdrawn before the Senate acted upon it.
Took oath of office, but did not proceed to post.
Not commissioned; nomination withdrawn before the Senate acted upon it.
Nomination of July 11, 1989, withdrawn on June 26, 1990.
Nomination of June 24, 2010, returned to the President on December 22, 2010.
